Award.AwardTitle: Northeast Conferences on Geometry and Topology of 4-Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Northeast Conferences on Geometry and Topology of 4-manifolds" series will have two meetings in 2015-2016, both at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. The first conference, entitled "Geometry and Topology of Symplectic 4-Manifolds," will meet between April 24-26, 2015, and the second, entitled "Floer Homologies, Gauge Theory, and Topology of 4-Manifolds," will meet in fall 2016. The conference series focuses on the geometry and topology of 4-manifolds, regarded as a melting pot for various research areas, such as low dimensional topology, contact, symplectic, complex and differential geometry, geometric analysis, and mathematical physics. The organizers plan to bring together leading experts and rising young researchers from across the country as speakers for each meeting and to support participation of interested researchers and graduate students, especially from the institutions in the Northeast. An objective of the conference series is to fertilize new research directions by increasing interaction and collaboration among the wealth of geometers and topologists in Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, particularly among graduate students, junior researchers, and their more senior colleagues, while providing all with a panorama of the subject area through a variety of talks and discussion sessions. The series will help build a regional network and support ties among graduate students, faculty, and other researchers throughout the Northeast.

The themes for both conferences are chosen from the most active and dynamic fields in recent years. Taubes' work connecting Seiberg-Witten gauge theory and symplectic topology has had great impact on both symplectic geometry and 4-dimensional smooth topology, while work of Donaldson and Gompf has led to many new constructions and applications of Lefschetz fibrations. The advances led to deep understanding of the internal structure of symplectic 4-manifolds. Remarkably, this led to the complete smooth and symplectic classification of symplectic 4-manifolds of negative Kodaira dimension. These will be the main topics of the first conference. On the other hand, gauge theory has had an enormous impact on the study of smooth 4-manifolds, starting with the seminal work of Donaldson in the 1980's and the introduction of Seiberg-Witten theory some 10 years later. Coupled with new methods for building 4-manifolds, this has led to the constructions of exotic smooth manifolds in many homotopy types, and to an understanding of the internal structure of smooth 4-manifolds. The deepest results of recent years have been based on the use of gauge theoretic invariants of 3-manifolds known as Floer homology theories, which give rise in turn to invariants of 4-manifolds with boundary. The second conference will focus on these invariants for all smooth 4-manifolds.

Web link for the Spring 2015 conference: http://people.math.umass.edu/~baykur/Symplectic4manifoldsConference.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
An objective of the Northeast Conferences on Geometry and Topology of 4-Manifolds is to increase interaction and collaboration between the wealth of geometers and topologists in Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, particularly between graduate students, junior researchers and their more senior colleagues, while providing all with a panorama of the subject area through a variety of talks and discussion sessions.

These conferences, along with the PIs earlier workshop in Fall 2013 on "Group actions on smooth 4-manifolds", are intended to initiate a new tradition: having 4-manifolds as a meeting point of different active research areas, such as low dimensional topology, contact, symplectic, complex and differential geometry, representation theory, geometric analysis and mathematical physics, each conference will narrow down the theme, while allowing contributions from diverse angles; these meetings are planned to consolidate future research directions by exposing the cutting-edge research, ideas and works of leading experts and young researchers from across the country to a broad list of participants from the Northeastern states, particularly graduate students. This conference series is expected to energize the field with diverse connections, education of young researchers and graduate students.

The participation of junior mathematicians and graduate students, with opportunities to interact with leading experts invited to our conferences, is one of the main goals of the conference series. These meetings are sought to help with building a regional network and support ties among researchers, graduate students and faculty throughout Northeast. This will not only help students with their research, but will also create an opportunity for building their professional network. 

With these objectives in mind, the two PIs on this grant, R. Inanc Baykur (UMass Amherst) and Weimin Chen (UMass Amherst), together with Daniel Ruberman (Brandeis), organized three very successful conferences within the (extended) grant period 04/01/2015 - 12/31/2018:

1. Geometry and topology of symplectic 4-manifolds
University of Massachusetts, Amherst, April 24-26, 2015
webpage: http://people.math.umass.edu/~baykur/Symplectic4manifoldsConference.html

2. Floer homologies and topology of 4-manifolds
University of Massachusetts, Amherst, April 8-9, 2017
webpage: http://people.math.umass.edu/~baykur/FloerHomologyConference.html

3. Knotted surfaces in 4-manifolds
University of Massachusetts, Amherst, October 26-28, 2018
webpage: http://people.math.umass.edu/~baykur/KnottedSurfacesConference.html

Each one of these meetings were attended by 60-80 mathematicians, about half of whom were graduate students. Each meeting focused on a different topic (related to 4-manifolds), and featured talks by a balanced combination of leading experts, rising researchers and graduate students. As part of the PIs commitment to provide opportunities for all members of the mathematical community to participate in advanced research meetings, they made every effort to encourage participation of colleagues from traditionally under-represented groups, women and ethnic minorities in particular. A particularly important component of these meetings was the inclusion of extended discussion sessions, where open and important problems in the focused area and ideas for solving them were presented for the benefit of young mathematicians and graduate students looking for interesting research problems, while creating leverage to reconsolidate ideas and techniques of researchers with different skills and backgrounds. Several new collaborations took place in these meetings, some of which resulted in excellent research articles.
